title: Tulane University Commencement 2009 - Ellen DeGeneres

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary driver of human behavior, according to motivation theories?
Which of the following is an example of an intrinsic motivator?
What is the name of the theory that proposes that human behavior is motivated by different levels of needs, ranging from basic physiological needs to self-actualization?
Which of the following emotions is often associated with the "fight or flight" response?
What is the term for the process by which we learn to associate certain stimuli with emotional responses?
Which of the following is an example of an extrinsic motivator?
Who is the psychologist that developed the theory of self-efficacy, which suggests that our motivation to perform a task is influenced by our confidence in our ability to succeed?
What is the term for the feeling of being "in the zone" or fully engaged in an activity, which is often associated with high levels of motivation and performance?
Which of the following is a characteristic of a person with high emotional intelligence?

options.label: A
options.text: They are easily upset by criticism

options.label: B
options.text: They have difficulty empathizing with others

options.label: C
options.text: They are able to recognize and regulate their own emotions

options.label: D
options.text: They are prone to impulsive behavior

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the tendency to attribute our own behavior to external factors, while attributing the behavior of others to their internal dispositions?

title: In praise of slowness - Carl Honore

multiple-choice.question: What is the supreme irony of publishing a book about slowness, according to the author?

options.label: A
options.text: The book becomes a bestseller quickly.

options.label: B
options.text: The author has to promote the book quickly.

options.label: C
options.text: The book is only read by slow readers.

options.label: D
options.text: The book is only sold in slow-paced cities.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the "Roadrunner form of living" that the author describes?

options.label: C
options.text: Damage to our health, diet, work, relationships, and environment.

options.label: D
options.text: A stronger sense of community and connection.

multiple-choice.question: What was the author's wake-up call to slow down?

options.label: C
options.text: Reading bedtime stories to his son and realizing he was speed-reading.

multiple-choice.question: What is the International Slow Movement, according to the author?

options.label: A
options.text: A global effort to speed up daily life.

options.label: B
options.text: A movement to promote fast food and fast fashion.

options.label: C
options.text: A backlash against the culture of speed and busyness.

options.label: D
options.text: A campaign to reduce working hours and increase productivity.

multiple-choice.question: What is the Slow Food Movement, and where did it start?

options.label: A
options.text: A movement to promote fast food, started in the USA.

options.label: B
options.text: A movement to promote slow and sustainable food, started in Italy.

options.label: C
options.text: A movement to reduce food waste, started in the UK.

options.label: D
options.text: A movement to increase food production, started in China.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of slowing down in the workplace, according to the author?

options.label: C
options.text: Improved quality of life and hourly productivity.

multiple-choice.question: What is the impact of the "quick fix mentality" in conventional medicine, according to the author?

options.label: A
options.text: Improved health outcomes and patient satisfaction.

options.label: B
options.text: Reduced healthcare costs and increased efficiency.

options.label: C
options.text: Deep disillusionment and a turn to alternative forms of medicine.

options.label: D
options.text: Increased use of technology and pharmaceuticals.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's view on the cultural taboo against slowing down?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a necessary part of modern life.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a result of the increasing pace of technology.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a major obstacle to adopting a slower pace of life.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a myth with no basis in reality.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's personal experience with slowing down?

options.label: A
options.text: He has always been a slow and relaxed person.

options.label: B
options.text: He has struggled to slow down and still enjoys the adrenaline rush of speed.

options.label: C
options.text: He has given up all fast-paced activities and adopted a completely slow lifestyle.

options.label: D
options.text: He has seen no benefits from slowing down and has returned to his fast-paced lifestyle.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's conclusion about the possibility of slowing down?

options.label: A
options.text: It is impossible in today's fast-paced world.

options.label: B
options.text: It is only possible for certain individuals or groups.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a resounding yes, and he presents himself as a reformed "speedoholic".

options.label: D
options.text: It is only possible through drastic changes to one's lifestyle.

title: How to use expertsâ€”and when not to - Noreena Hertz

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is a major problem in our society, culture, and as individuals?

options.label: A
options.text: We do not have enough experts.

options.label: B
options.text: We have become addicted to experts and their certainty.

options.label: C
options.text: We are not using the internet enough to find information.

options.label: D
options.text: We are not reading enough books to educate ourselves.

multiple-choice.question: What happened to the independent decision-making parts of the brains of a group of adults when they listened to experts speak in an MRI machine?
According to studies, what percentage of the time do doctors misdiagnose patients?
What is the speaker's profession?
According to the speaker, what is a common thinking error of radiologists when they look at CT scans?

options.label: A
options.text: They are overly influenced by the patient's symptoms.

options.label: B
options.text: They are overly influenced by whatever the referring physician has said.

options.label: C
options.text: They are not looking at the scans carefully enough.

options.label: D
options.text: They are not using the correct technology.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a company that has successfully used "democratized expertise" to make better decisions?
What strategy does Google's CEO Eric Schmidt use to encourage dissent in meetings?

options.label: A
options.text: He looks for the person who is most in agreement with him.

options.label: B
options.text: He looks for the person who is most vocal in their opinions.

options.label: C
options.text: He looks for the person who is arms crossed and looking bemused.

options.label: D
options.text: He looks for the person who is not paying attention.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the conventional notion of expertise?

options.label: A
options.text: Expertise is the preserve of anyone who has knowledge or experience in a particular area.

options.label: B
options.text: Expertise is the preserve of surgeons and CEOs.

options.label: C
options.text: Expertise is the preserve of people with advanced degrees and fancy titles.

options.label: D
options.text: Expertise is the preserve of people who have written best-selling books.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's main argument about experts?

options.label: A
options.text: We should trust experts completely and follow their advice without question.

options.label: B
options.text: We should never trust experts and always make our own decisions.

options.label: C
options.text: We should be skeptical of experts and challenge their opinions.

options.label: D
options.text: We should only trust experts who have a lot of experience.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the key to making better decisions in the 21st century?

options.label: B
options.text: Being aware of the limitations of experts and our own limitations

options.label: C
options.text: Using the internet to find information

options.label: D
options.text: Reading more books to educate ourselves

title: On being a woman and a diplomat - Madeleine Albright

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of the snake pin worn by Secretary Albright during her time as Ambassador to the United Nations?

options.label: A
options.text: It was a symbol of her love for snakes.

options.label: B
options.text: It was a gift from Saddam Hussein.

options.label: C
options.text: It was worn in response to a poem comparing her to an "unparalleled serpent."

options.label: D
options.text: It was a symbol of her opposition to the Gulf War.

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the book that accompanied Secretary Albright's pin collection?
How did Secretary Albright feel about the media attention focused on her clothing and appearance?

options.label: A
options.text: She enjoyed the attention and saw it as a way to promote her diplomatic work.

options.label: B
options.text: She was neutral and saw it as a necessary part of being a public figure.

options.label: C
options.text: She found it irritating and felt that it detracted from her work as a diplomat.

options.label: D
options.text: She saw it as an opportunity to showcase her fashion sense.

multiple-choice.question: Who advised Secretary Albright to "get rid of her professor clothes" and dress more like a diplomat?
What was the turning point for Secretary Albright in terms of finding her voice as a woman in a male-dominated field?

options.label: A
options.text: When she became Secretary of State

options.label: B
options.text: When she was appointed Ambassador to the United Nations

options.label: C
options.text: During her first meeting at the UN Security Council

options.label: D
options.text: When she was criticized for wearing a certain outfit

multiple-choice.question: How did Secretary Albright's granddaughter view her role as Secretary of State?

options.label: A
options.text: She saw it as a remarkable achievement and a source of pride.

options.label: B
options.text: She saw it as a normal part of life, since "only girls are Secretary of State."

options.label: C
options.text: She was too young to understand the significance of the role.

options.label: D
options.text: She saw it as a negative influence on her family life.

multiple-choice.question: Why did Secretary Albright believe that women's issues should be central to American foreign policy?

options.label: A
options.text: Because she was a feminist and wanted to promote women's rights.

options.label: B
options.text: Because she believed that societies are better off when women are politically and economically empowered.

options.label: C
options.text: Because she saw it as a way to promote American interests abroad.

options.label: D
options.text: Because she believed that women's issues were a "soft" issue that needed to be addressed.

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of Secretary Albright's efforts to include women judges on the war crimes tribunal for the Balkans?

options.label: A
options.text: The tribunal was unable to declare rape as a war crime.

options.label: B
options.text: The tribunal declared rape as a war crime, but only in certain circumstances.

options.label: C
options.text: The tribunal declared rape as a war crime and a crime against humanity.

options.label: D
options.text: The tribunal was unable to prosecute war crimes due to lack of evidence.

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the caucus formed by Secretary Albright and other women permanent representatives at the UN?
What was Secretary Albright's motto regarding women's relationships with each other?

options.label: A
options.text: "Women should support each other in all endeavors."

options.label: B
options.text: "There's a special place in hell for women who don't help each other."

options.label: C
options.text: "Women should prioritize their careers above all else."

options.label: D
options.text: "Women should focus on their families and communities first."

title: See Yemen through my eyes - Nadia Al-Sakkaf

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of the picture showing women and men leading a mixed protest in Yemen?

options.label: A
options.text: It highlighted the popularity of the president.

options.label: B
options.text: It demonstrated the need for change in the country.

options.label: C
options.text: It showed the traditional roles of men and women in Yemen.

options.label: D
options.text: It emphasized the importance of foreign aid.

multiple-choice.question: According to Nadia, what percentage of the Yemeni population is 15 years and below?
How did Nadia's father encourage her and her siblings?

options.label: A
options.text: He encouraged only the boys to pursue education and careers.

options.label: B
options.text: He encouraged the girls to stay at home and take care of domestic duties.

options.label: C
options.text: He encouraged both boys and girls to pursue education and careers, emphasizing their equality.

options.label: D
options.text: He discouraged them from pursuing higher education.

multiple-choice.question: What was Nadia's role in the Yemen Times after her brother's tenure as Editor-in-Chief?

options.label: C
options.text: She left the newspaper to pursue other interests.

multiple-choice.question: What award did the Yemen Times win in 2006?

options.label: B
options.text: The IPI Free Media Pioneer Award.

multiple-choice.question: According to Nadia, what is the key factor in empowering women in Yemen to remove their veils and assert their independence?
How did Nadia encourage young girls to assert their independence in the workplace?

options.label: A
options.text: She encouraged them to wear the veil at all times.

options.label: B
options.text: She discouraged them from pursuing careers in journalism.

options.label: C
options.text: She encouraged them to remove their veils in the office and on assignments.

options.label: D
options.text: She advised them to prioritize their domestic duties over their careers.

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the Yemen Times' independent reporting and criticism of those in power?

options.label: A
options.text: The newspaper was widely praised and supported by the government.

options.label: B
options.text: The newspaper was closed down several times, and its reporters were arrested.

options.label: C
options.text: The newspaper was sold to a new owner who changed its editorial policy.

options.label: D
options.text: The newspaper became a mouthpiece for the government.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the documentary that showcases a different side of Yemen, featuring young Yemeni men who express themselves through breakdancing and rap?
According to Nadia, what is the main reason for the Western press's often inaccurate or stereotypical portrayal of Yemen and other countries in the region?

options.label: D
options.text: Limited access to information and resources.

According to the speaker, what is often overestimated in achieving success?

options.text: At the TED conference in California

title: One is one...or is it? - Christopher Danielson

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea behind whole number place value, decimal place value, and fractions?

options.text: To change the way we count numbers

options.label: B
options.text: To change what we count as "one"

options.label: C
options.text: To change the way we write numbers

options.label: D
options.text: To change the way we add numbers

multiple-choice.question: What are the two ways to change units in our whole number system?
What is an example of a composed unit?
What is an example of a partitioned unit?
What can be done to composed units and partitioned units?

options.label: A
options.text: Only composed units can be partitioned

options.label: B
options.text: Only partitioned units can be composed

options.label: C
options.text: Composed units can be composed, and partitioned units can be partitioned

options.label: D
options.text: Composed units can be partitioned, and partitioned units can be composed

options.label: A
options.text: A box of toaster pastries is a single unit

options.label: B
options.text: A box of toaster pastries is composed of composed units

options.label: C
options.text: A box of toaster pastries is partitioned into partitioned units

options.label: D
options.text: A box of toaster pastries is not related to units

multiple-choice.question: Why do we write a one and a zero to represent the number 10?

options.label: A
options.text: To show that 10 is a large number

options.label: B
options.text: To show that 10 is a small number

options.label: C
options.text: To show that 10 is a unit, and the one represents one group

options.label: D
options.text: To show that 10 is not a unit

multiple-choice.question: What does the number 100 represent in terms of units?

options.label: D
options.text: 100 can be one thing, 10 things, or 100 things, depending on the unit

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the number one in math?

options.label: A
options.text: One is always a small number

options.label: B
options.text: One is always a large number

options.label: C
options.text: One is a unit, and its value can change depending on the context

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of the transcript in relation to math?

options.label: A
options.text: Math is always certain and absolute

options.label: B
options.text: Math is never certain and absolute

options.label: C
options.text: Math is dependent on the unit, and the value of one can change

options.label: D
options.text: Math is not dependent on the unit

title: The difference between winning and succeeding - John Wooden

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the definition of success that he coined in 1934?

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Winning every game or achieving a high grade in the classroom.

multiple-choice.question: What was the speaker's motivation for creating his own definition of success?

options.text: He wanted to be a better teacher and give his students something to aspire to.

options.label: B
options.text: To never try to be better than someone else, but to learn from others and be the best you can be.

title: National grid fully charged

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.text: The balance between generation and supply

options.label: D
options.text: The frequency of transmission line maintenance

options.label: A
options.text: By manually turning them on and off

options.label: B
options.text: By adjusting the settings on the transmission network

options.label: C
options.text: By submitting costs in advance and calling off the most expensive first

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Storing excess energy generated by renewables

options.text: By pumping water up to a reservoir for later use

options.label: C
options.text: By selling it to other countries

options.text: It reduces the strain on the grid during peak hours

options.label: B
options.text: It increases the demand for electricity during off-peak hours

options.label: C
options.text: It helps to level out the demand curve

options.label: B
options.text: By optimizing the throughput of existing transmission lines

options.label: C
options.text: By using smart meters to manage demand

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: They enable the National Grid to dispatch generation more efficiently

options.label: C
options.text: They help consumers to respond to price signals and drive efficiency

title: Measuring what makes life worthwhile - Chip Conley

multiple-choice.question: What was the speaker's initial goal when he started his company, Joie de Vivre?

options.label: A
options.text: To create a successful hotel chain

options.label: C
options.text: To make a profit in the hotel industry

title: Re-thinking progress: The circular economy

options.text: The increase in renewable energy use

options.label: C

options.text: To license technologies from manufacturers rather than owning them

options.label: D

options.label: D

options.label: C
